ygData.subject: Re: Robotic Manipulator
ygData.msgSnippet: Rohini, Yes I believe NEAT should do well in this domain.   Here is Moriarty s old paper on evolving obstacle avoidance for a robot arm using SANE:

Rohini,

Yes I believe NEAT should do well in this domain.   Here is 
Moriarty's old paper on evolving obstacle avoidance for a robot arm 
using SANE:  

http://nn.cs.utexas.edu/downloads/papers/moriarty.obstacle.pdf

David Moriarty invented SANE in the same research group as mine 
several years before I was there.

ken

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Rohini Kumar BRP <barla_rohini@y...> 
wrote:
> Hi,
> The problem is like a robotic manipulator with 3DOF. which is 
planar model..so only x and y co-ordinates. Its like finding some 
path from the current configuration to the goal state. And it has 
some obstracles (polygons) in the workspace. And for the simulator 
paty I am writing my own one. It is limited to reaching problem. Can 
u give me some references for the similar problem done in 
nueroevolution. So it seems i can go with NEAT for my thesis.
>  
> Regards,
> Rohini 
> 
> Colin Green <cgreen@d...> wrote:
> Rohini Kumar BRP wrote:
> 
> >Hi,
> >I am Rohini, new to this group. I am doing my MTech
> >thesis on REACHING WITH A ROBOTIC MANUPULATOR WITH
> >FEEDBACK, at Indian Institute of Technology, Kanpur
> >(India).
> >After going through your work (NEAT), I have a small
> >query which is as below:
> > Can NEAT evolve the required network for the robotic
> >manupulator(2D) to reach any point in the space
> >without collision? If yes please guide me.
> >  
> >
> 
> Hi,
> 
> Could you describe the problem in more detail? e.g. when you say 
that 
> the manipulator is 2D do you mean that the manipulator moves on an 
x,y 
> axis and can pick up and drop objects in a 2D plane? Are there 
objects 
> of  differents shapes and sizes that need to be detected by the 
network?
> 
> It's possible NEAT could evolve a network for your problem but you 
> really need to simulate the problem in code for a NEAT experiment. 
Is 
> there existing simulation code you could use?
> 
> Regards,
> 
> Colin
>
